title: Risk

description.plain:
In her upbeat track “Risk,” Gracie anxiously pleads for her the success of her romantic adventure. Singing in a cadence similar to a person in a panic attack, or simply confessing their love, she outlines the risks associated with her pursuing this fling, and mentions how no matter what, she wants to be in a relationship with them.

This song signals a shift in Gracie’s attitudes toward relationships and her self-image. In previous tracks from her debut album, Good Riddance, she continuously blamed her anxiousness and self-doubt for the failure of her relationship. This was evident on tracks such as “Best,” “Where do we go now?,” and “Difficult.” However, in “Risk,” she is ready to go all in into this new possibility with little doubt.

This is the first single from her sophomore album The Secret of Us. She released it with a music video. In the song’s visual, Gracie seems to be stuck in a loop, between the real world and her dreams/imagination. As the video progresses, Gracie becomes more love drunk, symbolized by her drinking more wine and acting erratically. She can also be seen following a male figure throughout the video, possibly her new interest. Although she used to describe driving to her lover’s house but never going in, this time it is different. Elated with the feeling of love, and breaking free from all the anxiousness and self-doubt, she crashes a birthday party, and causes a scene. Finally, we can see her going her separate way, rejoicing in her new found freedom and waking up ecstatic. The video was written and directed by Audrey Hobert.

embed_content: Read “Risk” by Gracie Abrams on Genius
